questions.text: The membrane potential of a particular cell is at the K+ equilibrium. The intracellular concentration for K+ is at 150 mmol/L and the extracellular concentration for K+ is at 5.5 mmol/L. What is the resting potential?
questions.solution:
• Resting membrane potential (RMP) = ∑K+ = ±61 log = -90mv
  • Ci= concentration inside.
  • Co= concentration outside.
  • RMP is present in all living cell and it is due to K+ (potassium) either Eflux of Influx

choices.text: Provides a structural component for cell movement
Is defined as the "functional" form of actin in the cell
Refers to the actin subunits that provide the molecular building blocks of the extended actin molecules found in the cell
Provides the molecular architecture for cell to cell communication

questions.text: F-actin is a component of the cellular cytoskeleton that
questions.solution:
• Actin
    • G. actin →monomer
    • F. actin →polymer
  • Functions of Actin
    1. Cell motility → Eg: listeria monocytogenes- tumbling motility due to polymerization of F actin molecule
    2. Along with myosin it helps in muscle contraction.
  • Opt. B - F actin is defined as "filamentous" form of actin in the cell.

choices.text: Carbohydrate sequences in bacterial cell walls

questions.text: Cells responsible for innate immunity are activated most commonly by
questions.solution:
• We have "pattern Recognition" on our cells and they are carbohydrate sequence in bacterial cell walls.
  • These sequence is identified by innate immunity.
  • Eg: Toll like receptor.

choices.text: Antigen presentation in the context of MHC-II
Gene rearrangements producing T cell receptors

questions.text: A biotechnology company is working to design a new therapeutic strategy for cancer that involves triggering an enhanced immune response to cellular proteins that are mutated in the disease. Which of the following immune cells or processes will most likely not be required for a successful therapy?
questions.solution:
• Antigen presentation in the context of MHC-II
  • MHC-II - CD4 →Antigen presenting cell (APC) of Macrophage.
  • When ever any antigen enters into body it is recognized by Macrophage and presented to T-cell via MHC-II
  • But the cancerous cells are presented by MHC-I
  • MHC I - CD8 → also for viral cells/ mutated cells & cancerous cells.

questions.text: A six-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of progressive excessive thirst, increased urination, weight loss, and severe fatigue. A glucose tolerance test results in a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus and the patient is treated effectively with injected insulin. The emergent symptoms in this patient reflect a failure of which immune process?
questions.solution:
• Normally our body cells are tolerant for immunity.
  • If failure of tolerance occurs then Auto immune disorder occurs.
  • Eg: Myasthenia Graris
  • Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
  • Type-I Diabetes.

choices.text: A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. This arm is paralyzed when he awakens, but it tingles, and pain sensation in it is still intact. The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is:
questions.solution:
• Motor function carried by A fibres.
  • Chronic pain carried by C fibres.
  • The Arm under his head describes pressure over the hand.
  • Sequence of fibres effected by pressure: A > B > C.

questions.text: Primary erythromelalgia, which may be due to a peripheral nerve sodium channelopathy, was diagnosed in a 13-year-old girl who was experiencing frequent episodes of red, painful, warm extremities. Which part of a neuron has the highest concentration of Na+ channels per square micrometer of cell membrane?
questions.solution:
• In Myelinated Neurons, at the Node of Ranvier more concentration of Na+ channels are present
  • This is the reason Action potential (AP) is more faster in myelinated neurons.

choices.text: NGF is made up of one α, two β, and one γ polypeptide subunits

NGF uses orthograde transport to move from the soma to the nerve terminal of a neuron
NGF binds to both p75 receptor and Trk receptor

questions.text: Neurotrophins foster the production of proteins associated with neuronal development, growth, and survival. Which of the following statements about nerve growth factor (NGF) is true?
questions.solution:
• Insulin + All Growth factors except TGF β act through Trk A receptors (Tyrosine kinase A)
  • NGF also equally binds to P75

choices.text: A decrease in extracellular Ca2+ concentration would stabilize the membrane and reduce its excitability
A decrease in the extracellular Na+ concentration would reduce the size of the resting membrane potential
An increase in the extracellular K+ concentration would move the resting membrane potential from a normal value of -90 mV to -70 mV
A decrease in the extracellular K+ concentration increases the gradient for K+ to leak out of the neuron, making the cell more hyperpolarized

questions.text: A medical student was working in a neurophysiology lab and was learning factors that determine the resting membrane potential of a neuron. Which of the following statements correctly explains how a change in concentration of an ion inside or outside of the neuron would change its resting membrane potential?
questions.solution:
• RMP changes are due to K+ efflux
  • In ↑K+ (Hyperkalemia) - RMP decreases Depolarization.
  • In ↓K+ (HypoKalemia) - RMP Increase Hyperpolarization.
  • Ca+2 will increase the excitability of membrane

choices.text: Are activated by strong pressure, severe cold, severe heat, and chemicals

Are innervated by group II aserents

questions.text: Nociceptors
questions.solution:
Nociceptors are Transient receptor potential.

  2. Menthol Receptor - by cold.

choices.text: And vestibular pathway contain a synapse in the cerebellum

Is composed of afferent fibers of the eighth cranial nerve, the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei, the inferior colliculi, the medial geniculate body, and the auditory cortex

questions.text: The auditory pathway
questions.solution:
• Pneumonic: E COLI MA
    • E - Eight cranial Nerve.
    • C - dorsal and ventral Cochlear nuclei.
    • O - Superior Olivary Nucleus
    • L - Lateral Geniculate body.
    • I - Inferior Colliculus.
    • M - Medial Lemniscus.
    • A - Auditory cortex.

choices.text: is epithelial tissue that contains photoreceptors

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with severe myopia made an appointment to see his ophthalmologist when he began to notice flashing lights and floaters in his visual field. He was diagnosed with a retinal detachment. The retina
questions.solution:
• A - The retina is Neural tissue that contain photo receptors.
  • B - lines the posterior 2/3 of the choroid.
  • C - Inner Nuclear layer - has Bipolar cells, Horizontal cells, Amacrine cells.
  • Outer Nuclear layer - has Rods & Cones.
  • D - contain ganglion cells whose axons form the optic Nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the eye has the greatest concentration of rods?
questions.solution:
• Maximum cones concentrated at Fovea Region.
  • Maximum Rods concentrated at Para foveal Region.

questions.text: The functions of tropomyosin in skeletal muscle include
questions.solution:
• Tropomyosin is Relaxing protein, because it covers myosin binding site on actin filament and Relaxing muscle.
  • Only when Ca+2 comes & attaches to Troponin C then it causes confirmational change to uncover Myosin binding site on actin filament and cause contraction.

questions.text: In the utricle, tip links in hair cells are involved in
questions.solution:
• All the vestibular apparatus has hair cells.

  • When the movement occurs bend towards tallest hair cell (Kinocellium) → Entry of K+ (influx) → Depolarization
  • Due to distorted - activated ion channel.
  • Bent away from Kinocellium → Hyperpolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following would be least likely to be seen 14 days after a rat is injected with a drug that kills all of its pancreatic B cells?
questions.solution:
• The above condition is DKA (Diabetic Keto acidosis)
  • The given Drug → Kill all pancreatic B Cells →No Insulin/Insulin deficiency
  • DKA
  • To compensate Acidosis
    • The rise in plasma concentration of H+
    • A Fall in plasma HCo3 Concentration.
  • A rise in plasma Glucagon concentration - to compensate Hypoglycemia.
  • A rise in plasma osmolality- due to ↑ in Glucose

questions.text: Water is absorbed in the jejunum, ileum, and colon and excreted in the feces. Arrange these in order of the amount of water absorbed or excreted from greatest to smallest.

questions.solution: Enterokinase helps in protein digestion by converting trypsinogen to Trypsin

questions.solution: The short chain fatty acids produced by Gut flora is absorbed maximum at colon.

questions.text: Gastric pressures seldom rise above the levels that breach the lower esophageal sphincter, even when the stomach is filled with a meal, due to which of the following processes?
questions.solution: • Stomach accommodates food because it has a property of receptive Relaxation and plasticity.

questions.text: Compared to hepatic bile, gallbladder bile contains a reduced concentration of which of the following?
questions.solution: The concentration of solids (Table 28–3); hepatic bile is 97%water, whereas the average water content of gallbladder bile is89%. However, because the bile acids are a micellar solution, the micelles simply become larger, and since osmolarity is a colligative property, bile remains isotonic. However, bile becomes less alkaline as sodium ions are exchanged for protons (although the overall concentration of sodium ions rises with a concomitant loss of chloride and bicarbonate as the bile is concentrated).

questions.text: A surgeon is studying new methods of liver transplantation. She performs a complete hepatectomy in an experimental animal. Before the donor liver is grafted, a rise in the blood level of which of the following would be expected?
questions.solution:
• Precursor of vit D3 is present in liver so.
  • 25-Hydroxycholeciferol rises.
  • In Kidney it forms active Vit D3
